means: 使懊恼，使懊丧，使悔恨( chagrin的过去式和过去分词 )

sentence.Network_en: The chair of the committee did not appear chagrined by the compromises and delays.
sentence.Network_cn: 委员会主席对于这些妥协和拖延似乎并不显得懊恼。

sentence.Network_en: I was most chagrined when I heard that he had got the job instead of me.
sentence.Network_cn: 当我听说是他而不是我得到了那份工作时懊恼极了.

sentence.Network_en: He was [ felt ] chagrined at his failure [ at losing his pen ].
sentence.Network_cn: 他为自己的失败 [ 遗失钢笔 ] 而感到懊恼.

entry.def: If you are chagrined by something, it disappoints, upsets, or annoys you, perhaps because of your own failure.

example.ex: The chair of the committee did not appear chagrined by the compromises and delays.
example.tran: 委员会主席对于这些妥协和拖延似乎并不显得懊恼。

means.word_mean: 1. feeling or caused to feel uneasy and self-conscious;

sentences.sentence: "chagrined at the poor sales of his book"
